Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: Molecular mechanisms and physiological triggers underlying neuromodulator plasticity in a lobster pattern generator
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching goal of this project is to understand the processes that underlie variability in behavior. Specifically, the project will focus on variability in the responses of neuronal networks generating the activity that controls rhythmic movements to one hormone. This project will utilize the lobster cardiac neuromuscular system, a simple model for understanding this phenomenon. In this system, some hearts respond to the hormone allatostatin-C with increased contraction force, while others respond by decreasing contraction force. The project is multi-disciplinary, using physiological, molecular and biochemical approaches. Experiments will include recording changes in activity of the lobster heart when exposed to the hormone, using molecular biological techniques to determine the genes that contribute to the differential responses to the hormone in different animals, and analyzing proteins within the heart to determine how they differ among animals that respond differently to the hormone. This project is a collaboration between researchers at Bowdoin College (Brunswick, Maine) and the University of Hawaii at Manoa (Honolulu). It will train undergraduates, including underrepresented minority students, at both institutions in a wide variety of chemical, molecular and physiological techniques. It will provide interdisciplinary training and will introduce undergraduates to the importance of examining scientific questions from multiple perspectives. The molecular components of the project will also provide resources that can be used by other scientists to address additional issues in lobster biology, including the origin and physiological consequences of shell disease.

To determine the mechanisms and triggers that underlie the variability in the responses of neuronal networks to modulators, this project will examine a simple pattern generator, the lobster cardiac ganglion. This project will combine transcriptomics and physiology to look for differences in gene expression that correlate with differential responses to the peptide hormone, allatostatin-C. At the same time, the project will ask whether these differences may be triggered by changes related to the molt cycle. The project, which will use Illumina sequencing, will assemble de novo transcriptomes from lobster tissues. These transcriptomes will provide references onto which RNA-Seq data from lobsters that respond differentially to allatostatin-C in physiological experiments will be mapped to determine changes in gene expression. The investigation will target specific genes and will use a genome-wide assessment to look for additional changes. The project will also use mass spectrometry to ask whether specific proteins show different post-translational modifications in lobster hearts that respond differentially to the neuropeptide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had two major goals: (1) increasing our understanding of the mechanisms involved in generating flexibility in rhythmic patterns of movement, such as locomotion and heartbeat and (2) training undergraduate students in an interdisciplinary context, engaging them in looking at questions from a range of perspectives.

 

Rhythmic patterns of movements in all animals appear to be driven and coordinated by circuits of interacting nerve cells. The specific membrane properties of these neurons, as well as the pattern of connections among them, enable these circuits to generate consistent patterns of rhythmic outputs that in turn drive movement patterns. These patterns are intrinsically very stable, yet animals require variability in their behavioral outputs. Such variability derives largely from the actions of locally and/or hormonally released neuromodulators, which can alter aspects of a neuronal circuit and hence circuit output. Perhaps surprisingly, the responses to some of these modulators are themselves quite variable, with the same substance causing different changes in different animals. 

 

One rhythmic behavior that is controlled by such a neuronal circuit and is modulated by a wide range of molecules, particularly neuropeptides, is the lobster heart, which is controlled by the cardiac ganglion. The present project used the lobster heart system to begin examining variability in the response to a family of neuropeptides, the C-type allatostatins (AST-Cs). The lobster AST-C family includes three peptides, which differ slightly in amino acid sequence, but share important structural elements. Interestingly, the response to all three peptide isoforms varies among animals. This project compared the responses of the same hearts to each of the peptide isoforms, and found that the responses to two of the peptides, AST-C I and II, which share a non-amidated carboxyl-terminus, are more similar to one another than they are to the responses to the third isoform, AST-C II, which has an amidated carboxyl-terminus. Moreover, the responses to AST-C I and III were more variable than those to AST-C II.

 

One hypothesis to explain the variability in responses to the same peptides across animals is that there might be more than one receptor for these peptides, and that animals could have different balances of these receptors, leading to different responses to the same peptide across animals. To test this hypothesis, it was first necessary to uncover the identities of AST-C receptors and to determine whether more than one such receptor exists both in the species and in the cardiac ganglion. Thus, RNA was extracted from specific nervous system regions; the extracted RNA gives a snapshot of the transcripts that were available to be used as templates for making peptides and proteins in each tissue at the time the RNA was extracted. The RNA was sequenced to generate tissue-specific transcriptomes, i.e., collections of the RNA transcripts predicted to be present in each tissue. Searches of these transcriptomes suggested that RNA in the lobster nervous system encodes four putative AST-C receptors. Experiments are currently underway to confirm that these receptors are activated by AST-C and to determine whether the different AST-Cs activate the receptors differentially.

 

Additionally, RNA was extracted from the cardiac ganglia of preparations that showed a range of responses to the AST-Cs.  The RNA from these ganglia has been sequenced, and the sequence data are being used to assess whether receptor expression and physiological response are correlated.

 

To meet the second goal of this project, undergraduates worked on numerous independent research projects. Because this was a collaborative grant, students included undergraduates from both Bowdoin College and the University of Hawaii at Manoa. Students received intensive training in techniques and approaches used in one of the perspectives from which the problem was examined (e.g, physiology, bioinformatics, mass spectrometry); they were also exposed to and received training in other perspectives, so that they are comfortable thinking about cross-disciplinary approaches to problems. A number of students from each institution were able to spend a summer at the other institution, where they focused on a different way of approaching the central question. Over the course of the grant, five University of Hawaii undergraduates/post-  baccalaureate students (all women and/or from underrepresented groups) worked on the project and were trained in transcriptome analysis and protein prediction; two of these spent a summer at Bowdoin, where they also did physiological studies. Twenty-four Bowdoin undergraduates (including 15 women and one non-binary student), three high school students, one community college student, and four graduate/post-baccalaureate students worked directly on physiological/molecular aspects of this project at Bowdoin; an additional 11 focused on mass spectrometric approaches at Bowdoin. Four of the Bowdoin students spent a summer at the University of Hawaii, where they learned and used bioinformatics approaches to problems. An additional 31 students received similar training while working on related projects in the Dickinson lab at Bowdoin. Approximately 30 papers supported by this grant have been published, most with undergraduate co-authors.
